headline: Radical members of 'The Squad' use news conference to slam Israel
subHeadline: Top Democrats reportedly threaten to retaliate after Congresswomen Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar were denied access to Israel over their support of the BDS movement.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I am Jesse Watters along with Katie P., Juan Williams, Dana P., and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City and this is "The Five." Radical members of the squad slamming Israel just moments ago. This comes as top Democrats reportedly threatened to retaliate after Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar were banned from entering the country. The White House firing back against House Democrats plans to punish the U.S. and Israeli ambassadors with legislative action.  Tlaib and Omar were denied access to Israel over their support of a boycott movement. Israel later granted Tlaib access on humanitarian grounds but she turned it down. Omar also taking a swipe at President Trump.

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN OMAR (D-MN)
utterances.sentences: We know Donald Trump would love nothing more than to use this issue to pit Muslims and Jewish-Americans against each other. The Muslim community and the Jewish community are being othered and made in to the bogeyman by this administration.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Tlaib and Omar also under fire for sharing a controversial cartoon on social media by an anti-Semitic artist. This is President Trump blasting the pair as radical Dems saying, "They have such disdain for Israel." All right, Dana, the Democratic Party again on its heels over anti-Semitism and again looks like the face of the party as the squad, is this what Nancy Pelosi wants?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I was -- I probably shouldn't have been surprised that they had a press conference today, but I'm slightly surprised because I think that they could have turned the page, get it behind them, move on and to do something else.   But by having the press conference today and try to showcase that they just ensured, the White House is probably going to respond again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Every Democratic candidate on the campaign trail is going to have to answer it and the president's going say something and then we'll talk -- you know, we could go another week talking about this and I don't -- if -- my gut instinct is that they are not winning this argument. They might think they are winning the argument. It doesn't feel like it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What does it say, Greg, that they do think they are winning the argument?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, I think they have learned in this Trump era that conflict creates the news. So they are, I mean, we carried this press conference. We wouldn't probably carried a press conference like that a couple of years ago. I don't think we would, would we? You know, some minor politicians in Minnesota become national news and they love it. It's great for their brand. I think the left is in a fit though because how many people who never knew what the BDS movement was now know about it.  It sounds like a medical disorder that's advertised on cable. But it's like now, like, I watch the media when they talk about the BDS movement. They have to look down and they go the BDS movement stands for uh, what does it stand for?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Something divestments --

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Boycott --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Boycott, divestment, sanction. So it's like -- it's actually, again, in the Trump era, we are learning about stuff that we probably didn't learn about before and I don't think it helps them because once people learn about the BDS movement, they see its largely --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- its origins are anti-Semitic, much like the cartoon.  By the way, the cartoon wasn't very good --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- but the guy was a contestant in a holocaust denial contest. That's not a good book for the squad. But I go back -- can I go back to the one point about the new rules of engagement? Before Trump, this was a one- way street.   The far left factions, anti-Semitic factions, could wage war on Israel and you have to grin and bear it, right? You just have to take it. Now there's pushback and when you push back, they accuse you of being the bully.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you know what, it's not just conservatives pushing back. Bill Maher himself, pretty liberal guy, Juan, he came out and said the BDS movement was garbage and took a pretty hard position against the squad. And then Rashida Tlaib came back and said maybe we should boycott Bill Maher.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, first, let me just say that they are winning this argument.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You think so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think so. And just to, you know, --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What evidence is there that they're winning?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I don't think there's any question there's been a backlash. You see Republicans as well as Democrats, Jewish people as well as Muslims, all saying Israel should've let them in and don't forget, Netanyahu said he wanted to let them in until President Trump tweeted at him and asked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So Pelosi is happy with this, you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think very happy --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- because I think continuing this conversation to just double down on Greg's point, it makes more people aware of the boycott, divestment and sanctions movement than ever before --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that's a good thing?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- and I disagree with it but I must say, suddenly, everybody's talking about it. But I'll say this to you as well. I think this is killing the D.C. consensus of support for Israel. I think it's now becoming politically polarized, like so much.  You know, I remember when people were upset that Benjamin Netanyahu was invited by the Republicans to come to Congress and criticized President Obama. But, you know what, it went by. Now, this has been doubled down by Trump so that now everything is so political about Israel. And, you know, Democrats and Republicans for the longest time, look at our financial support, military support, pro-Israel. And now Netanyahu at Trump's behest is dividing that. There's going to be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Calling it an occupation is kind of a divisional.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- in the White House and they're going to, you know, put in a position --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And so the Israeli prime minister, he is the one that's being divisive, not the squad?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, I will agree with Juan on one thing. And that is, this does push the Democratic Party further away from Israel because Democrats are taking the side of Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar instead of a long-standing ally. And you could say, well, they are Americans, they are congresswomen, that is why we are doing it. But if you look at the record and why they were not allowed into the country, the group they are going with celebrate suicide bombers who not only kill Israelis but also Americans.   They glorify terrorists who kill children. So, that's one reason that they are left out. And during their press conference, and this is exactly what they are going for, they are talking about so much misinformation, right?  They are acting like this is about Benjamin Netanyahu when it's about BDS which is a movement that's been around for far longer than one political party either in the U.S. or in Israel. And it's about not allowing the country to exist. Rashida Tlaib talks about the walls in Israel not being effective. Actually, they are at keeping suicide bombers out of Israel. And so there's a lot of things that they're putting on the table that they don't want to talk about in terms of human rights that don't jive with the leftist narrative. Just today, the Palestinian authority banned all LGBTQ activity in the West Bank, while Israel has one of the largest gay rights parades in the world.   So they're going to have to figure out, Democrats, whether they actually support real human rights in the Middle East which come with Israel, including for Arab-Israelis, or whether they support two congresswomen who are associated with group who celebrate suicide bombings against American citizens.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And wasn't this whole thing exposed as a stunt, Greg, when the Israeli government let Tlaib come in to visit her grandmother on humanitarian grounds and then she said no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Who uses their grandmother as a prop? She wrote in a letter this may be the last time I see my grandmother, then she decides not to see her grandmother. And then -- but she finds time to post this other cartoon.   I'm going to say I don't trust her. I don't trust anybody that would use their grandmother in such a manner. She should apologize to her grandmother, Dana, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, also, the two of them could've gone on the trip the week before with 51 members of Congress -- 30 Republicans, 21 Democrats.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They could've all gone together and then -- and from what I heard from that trip, all views were expressed and these views could have been expressed --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, that's not what Kevin McCarthy says. Kevin McCarthy, Republican, leader of the Republicans in the House says, "Yes, they should've been let in. Everybody should go. But this is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, but I was saying they should've gone with the whole group.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think they have to go by anybody's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But aren't we paying for it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- members of the United States Congress.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Aren't we paying for it, Juan?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Should they go with a group?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Aren't we paying for them so it would be cheaper as a group.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- with this group.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Juan, should they go with the group that says anti-terrorism?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- members of Congress have always been allowed to go --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- without our president telling another nation's president --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: But not with this group.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- oh no, don't let my political opponents in. That to me is -- and now, this effort to say something about the ambassadors, they are just proxies for Netanyahu and Trump.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Can I just say one more thing about the aid point that Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib were making. They're saying well, we give Israel $3 billion in aid every year. Aid to Israel is actually an investment because in return for that they give us technology, they give us counterterrorism operations. They stop dozens of terrorist attacks last year in 20 different countries. The Palestinians use our aid, our taxpayer money to pay terrorists and their families to kill Americans and Israelis. So, that's the difference. What's the return on investment when it comes to Israel? We get a lot in return for the aid that we're giving them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And maybe they didn't go to Israel with the other delegation. Maybe they had an appointment that they couldn't change. Those things, you know, there are sometimes conflicts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- Netanyahu just had to comment and criticized an American president in our country. Maybe we should have kept him out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think Obama had denied entry to --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- someone from Israel. I think it was in 2012, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, stop.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, it goes both ways. Elizabeth Warren's DNA debacle is back and she's forced to apologize again for lying about her Cherokee heritage. See that, next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Elizabeth Warren seeing a surge in the polls but an old controversy continues to haunt her on the campaign trail. The 2020 Democratic hopeful apologizing again for to Native-Americans for her previous Cherokee heritage claims.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), PRESDIENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Like anyone who has been honest with themselves, I know that I have made mistakes. I am sorry for harm I have caused. I have listened and I have learned a lot. And I am grateful for the many conversations that we've had together. It is a great honor to be able to partner with Indian Country, and that's what I've tried to do as a senator, and that's what I promise I will do as president.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, that was her today at a big event, Jesse. Now, a contrary view could be that this speaks to the strength of her campaign that she went to this event knowing that she would have to do this even, you know, she could've had a scheduling conflict. Who knows when is a scheduling conflict, like a dentist appointment you can't change.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. I think it was a whitewash. The moderator of the event endorsed her. And then they agreed ahead of time that she would not be asked about her fake heritage claims. And then on the eve of the event, she scrubbed the video where she released her DNA results from her campaign website. So, she's got terrible political instincts and she's a phony. And what she did to Native Americans was -- some people say a lot worse than what Trump has done to minorities. If you think about what she did, she stole their identity. Then she use that fake identity to suppress the minorities' access to higher education jobs. And then she profited from the fake identity. And then when she got busted on it, when President Trump mocked her, she said "Oh, that's an ethnic slur, Pocahontas." That's about as an ethnic slur as Fredo. It doesn't even make any sense. What's happening now is she is up in the polls because she's getting some Bernie boroughs (ph) behind her. But she's got a very irritating demeanor. Black Americans don't really love her that much. Wall Street hates her. So, I think she's just -- it's another landslide victory for the president if she gets the nomination.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, one thing is, that the president said the other night in his rally that he had hit her hard on the issue, but now she's coming back so she's going to have to do it again. But because it's so competitive on the Democratic side, why do you think that none of the other Democrats go after her about it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I will tell you, as a black lesbian, I believe that it is important that she reach out to them to get this past her. Here's the problem though. What is she apologizing for? Like, I'm not sure. Because that amazing video that you mentioned scrubbed, vindicated her, right? She was 1/17000 Native American and she played that up, so. Is she apologizing for perpetuating the lie? Is she apologizing for the impersonation, the exaggeration or the exploitation? Remember, she used this to get ahead and the law school used her lie to get ahead by saying like, we have the first female minority lawyer. Was it Harvard, I believe? So, that's why I don't give anymore money to that school. But anyway, and the media, like Jesse said, will pay this as some kind of, like calling her fauxcahontas or whatever. It's like calling a dumb person Einstein, right? It's like -- so I just think that I'm confused, as you could tell. I don't know what she's apologizing for. Is she admitting she lied or -- she said she's Native American?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: In the Jonathan Martin "New York Times" piece last week, Juan, they said it was a story about her poll numbers better. And at the very end, they interviewed somebody who had gone to one of her events and they said, "She's so smart. She really has a plan." And the last line was, it's just that Pocahontas thing. And that was how he ended it. Is that on the minds in regards to electability against President Trump?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think people realize that this is what Trump has when it comes to Liz Warren. I mean, that's why he's back attacking her. She's rising in the polls. He goes after Sleepy Joe, who is Joe Biden, who's really on his mind and he's the most attacked by the president.  But now, she's back in the picture and again because she is a strong candidate and a rising -- she has momentum. I mean, the fact that she went to this forum, that she was invited to this forum, indicates in the words of the man who hosted the forum, that this is a trivial issue for Native Americans. They don't think it's a big deal. But what you get is a situation where, you know what, she has big ideas, Dana, and she has ideas, policy ideas. So for the Native Americans, what they say is this Pocahontas thing is Trump's agenda. That's the way he puts people down. And it's trivial to us. What's important to us, her -- Elizabeth Warren's top issues; health care, education, helping young people get ahead, pay for that big tuition debt. And, you know what, saying to the very rich people in this country, hey, no more protections. No more too big to fail. You got to pay your taxes and deal with (inaudible). People are reacting to her as a passionate advocate, including Native Americans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: One thing about her that's different to Hillary Clinton, Hillary Clinton never apologized for the e-mail scandal. And Elizabeth Warren has apologized a few times for this even though people aren't really sure what she apologized for.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: But she has never admitted that she's not Native American. She's never said she's not Cherokee. She has parsed this line between I've caused all this pain --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- I'm sorry for that, but she's never said I'm sorry for using the 1/1024th may be Cherokee argument to put on my bar card in Texas that I was Native American or to get that first status as the first woman of color at Harvard Law School. So, I'm not clear on what she's apologizing for either. And I think if she had not gone to the forum, it probably would have looked worse --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- because she would have been avoiding the issue. So, she was in a little bit, a little loose (ph)

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, it might be a sign of strength, I guess, for her and within the Democratic Party that she went, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Also, in other Native American news, "The Washington Post" did a poll among Native Americans and they asked, what was the number one emotion that you felt when you saw the Washington Redskin mascot? And you know what the top one was?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Pride.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Pride. They like it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Do you know my number one reaction is?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Disgust.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because they're going to go 0-16?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And guess what --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because the Eagles are going to beat them twice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, we got to tell the audience. That's my team. I just don't like that name. I don't like it at all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How do you think I feel about the San Francisco Giants? I am a below average height person. My favorite baseball team is the Giants, Dana. Everyday I wake up and I go, I have to root for a team that towers over my diminutive stance.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That you could never achieve.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I could never achieve.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, this is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How do you think I feel?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You know what, it's out of reach.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I am not a protected class, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I though you were a black lesbian.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, that's true. I'm a short one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, President Trump and conservatives are furious over a leaked transcript from "The New York Times" staff meeting. We're going to tell you what it says, next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All right. "The New York Times" being blasted for bias after a leaked transcript revealed its new plan to go after President Trump. The paper's executive editor forced to hold a crisis town hall meeting last week after liberal backlash for changing a headline about recent shootings.  From "Trump Urges Unity Versus Racism" To "Assailing Hate But Not Guns." In the leaked transcript, the editor, Dean Baquet, is quoted as saying, "We build our newsroom to cover one story. We did truly well." But after Russia collusion fell apart, the editor says his paper is focusing on a new narrative, race. Here's a quote -- "Now, we have to regroup and shift resources and emphasis to take on a different story." So, Jesse, this transcript is revealing but it also I think solidified a lot of what we already knew.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. Well, it was revealing in a sense that they admitted that they were unable to take out Trump. They have admitted that they are not as influential as they think they are. And they admitted they are not journalists, that they are partisan activists. Because a real journalist would go back the last two years and look, how did this Russia hoax actually come into being? But they are spending no time looking back. They have turned a blind eye to it and then are now just looking at what else can take out Trump. Race, I don't believe will have the same type of effect against the president as the Russia thing did. You could see the rating for the cables that pushed that hoax, are not rebounding as they pivot to race. And approval for Donald Trump among Hispanics and Black Americans since January has actually gone up. So, it's also not a very inspiring message to say that the country is founded on racism, it's a racist nation, and we need to destroy it and institute socialism in order to heal it. That type of messaging to this country is racist and that Trump is racist that all Trump voters are racist are going to turn off the very voters that the Democrats are going to need to recapture those rust belt districts in order to win back the White House because race isn't going to work. It's got to be health care, education, as Juan said, and jobs.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Juan, you look like you have something to say in response to that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I do your honor. And I just want to see my time to Mr. Watters because I think he is indicting himself and I just want more of his testimony. Russia hoax?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Did you miss the entire Mueller report that said Russia interfered in the 2016 --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The hoax was there. It's collusion Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- to help Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was the hoax.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- it was -- this is what -- there was no finding of any collusion, no investigation. It was an investigation to conspiracy and they didn't find a conspiracy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let's just move on.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Juan, as a journalist, do you think this type of conversation about activism --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let's just move on after he --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, because I said I would see the point to Jesse because I think he is indicting himself, but go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, as a journalist for many years --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- do you think that these conversations about the activism are appropriate?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well look, I think -- look, I just think you look at the numbers. We had a poll here at Fox last week -- it said two-thirds of Americans think he's tearing the country apart. And that includes by the way, more than 60 percent of white Americans. So, something is going on in terms of the social fabric. And if you're a journalist, how could you not pay attention to it. But to my mind, you know, it's like this is not a new topic for the "Times." "The Times" have been covering it. I think yesterday they had a magazine dedicated to slavery. So, this is something that they need to do. And I think that what you hear from Dean Baquet is look, we put a lot of effort into covering Mueller and the conspiracy argument, Jesse, and I think they did a pretty good job. They were way ahead of other people saying that they didn't think that Mueller was coming --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They didn't do a very good job, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think they -- in fact, I think they were ahead of saying, certainly, ahead of all those people who were over at the other channels feeding this conspiracy. They were not in that camp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait, the other channels follow everything that's written in "The Times."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM
utterances.sentences: I think they may, but they didn't do it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. The conspiracy is that they are creating a framework to shape the news to lay out a blueprint so you can just slot in all the stories about race. Whether the polls say that they think Trump is tearing the country apart is irrelevant because it's the media that is creating the narrative that people hear about. The fact is the curtain is now pulled back. We see this and we are surprised. The rest of the media smirks because it's been this way all along, the problem. So why are they doing this? It's because racism is a quantity where in the media, the demand exceeds the supply. So they're going to have to keep creating this. They're going to have to keep doing this. And to your point, that slave story, the slave article was probably -- I didn't read it, but I'm assuming it was probably well- researched. It was probably well done, but I didn't read it. But now, my assumptions are this is all part of a greater narrative to paint Donald Trump as racist. So I'm going to look at everything they do as somehow artificially constructed to demonize somebody, and it's not going to stop. It's going to get worse. And we have to admit, this country overtime gets less racist. Do you think we're more racist now than we were in the 60's or the 50's or the 1860's? It's getting better, but they don't like that story. Things are going so well that they need to demonize everybody. So, right now, the Gray Lady is - this is bigger than Watergate. Gray Lady is Nixon and drag at this point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But you know, you're right. I think things are getting better in terms of race.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Of course, they are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: In terms of like if I compare where my father was to where I am. I don't think there is any question. But I will say this look--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: End there, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Anybody - I'm sorry?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: End your point there that you agree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. Well, I know I was confirming something, but I think that anybody who has covered Trump as a real journalist knows that he has had trouble with the race issue all along. Federal suits about housing discrimination. The birther movement. Mexicans rape. I mean just I could go on Central Park Five. I wrote a book about this a year ago. utterances.sentences: And she came in third. So, I thought this was a very inspirational story for everybody who has been diagnosed with that disease that the sky's the limit even if you have some obstacles in the way.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Good for her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How old is she?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure how old she is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: She looks young. That's so sad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What's your max squat, Katie?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It used to be like 200. But not anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Really. Dana what's yours?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Round about 220.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: 220, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't squat weight, Jesse. I squat the human body.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, you always know how to put a finishing touch on this. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next with Bret.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Never know what you're going to get. Thanks, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's true. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2019 CQ-Roll Call, Inc. utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I am Jesse Watters along with Katie P., Juan Williams, Dana P., and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City and this is "The Five." Radical members of the squad slamming Israel just moments ago. This comes as top Democrats reportedly threatened to retaliate after Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar were banned from entering the country. The White House firing back against House Democrats plans to punish the U.S. and Israeli ambassadors with legislative action. Tlaib and Omar were denied access to Israel over their support of a boycott movement. Israel later granted Tlaib access on humanitarian grounds but she turned it down. Omar also taking a swipe at President Trump.

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN OMAR (D-MN)
utterances.utterance: We know Donald Trump would love nothing more than to use this issue to pit Muslims and Jewish-Americans against each other. The Muslim community and the Jewish community are being othered and made in to the bogeyman by this administration.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tlaib and Omar also under fire for sharing a controversial cartoon on social media by an anti-Semitic artist. This is President Trump blasting the pair as radical Dems saying, "They have such disdain for Israel." All right, Dana, the Democratic Party again on its heels over anti-Semitism and again looks like the face of the party as the squad, is this what Nancy Pelosi wants?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I was -- I probably shouldn't have been surprised that they had a press conference today, but I'm slightly surprised because I think that they could have turned the page, get it behind them, move on and to do something else. But by having the press conference today and try to showcase that they just ensured, the White House is probably going to respond again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Every Democratic candidate on the campaign trail is going to have to answer it and the president's going say something and then we'll talk -- you know, we could go another week talking about this and I don't -- if -- my gut instinct is that they are not winning this argument. They might think they are winning the argument. It doesn't feel like it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What does it say, Greg, that they do think they are winning the argument?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, I think they have learned in this Trump era that conflict creates the news. So they are, I mean, we carried this press conference. We wouldn't probably carried a press conference like that a couple of years ago. I don't think we would, would we? You know, some minor politicians in Minnesota become national news and they love it. It's great for their brand. I think the left is in a fit though because how many people who never knew what the BDS movement was now know about it. It sounds like a medical disorder that's advertised on cable. But it's like now, like, I watch the media when they talk about the BDS movement. They have to look down and they go the BDS movement stands for uh, what does it stand for?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Something divestments --

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Boycott --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Boycott, divestment, sanction. So it's like -- it's actually, again, in the Trump era, we are learning about stuff that we probably didn't learn about before and I don't think it helps them because once people learn about the BDS movement, they see its largely --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- its origins are anti-Semitic, much like the cartoon. By the way, the cartoon wasn't very good --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- but the guy was a contestant in a holocaust denial contest. That's not a good book for the squad. But I go back -- can I go back to the one point about the new rules of engagement? Before Trump, this was a one- way street. The far left factions, anti-Semitic factions, could wage war on Israel and you have to grin and bear it, right? You just have to take it. Now there's pushback and when you push back, they accuse you of being the bully.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you know what, it's not just conservatives pushing back. Bill Maher himself, pretty liberal guy, Juan, he came out and said the BDS movement was garbage and took a pretty hard position against the squad. And then Rashida Tlaib came back and said maybe we should boycott Bill Maher.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, first, let me just say that they are winning this argument.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.utterance: You think so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think so. And just to, you know, --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What evidence is there that they're winning?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I don't think there's any question there's been a backlash. You see Republicans as well as Democrats, Jewish people as well as Muslims, all saying Israel should've let them in and don't forget, Netanyahu said he wanted to let them in until President Trump tweeted at him and asked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So Pelosi is happy with this, you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think very happy --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- because I think continuing this conversation to just double down on Greg's point, it makes more people aware of the boycott, divestment and sanctions movement than ever before --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's a good thing?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- and I disagree with it but I must say, suddenly, everybody's talking about it. But I'll say this to you as well. I think this is killing the D.C. consensus of support for Israel. I think it's now becoming politically polarized, like so much. You know, I remember when people were upset that Benjamin Netanyahu was invited by the Republicans to come to Congress and criticized President Obama. But, you know what, it went by. Now, this has been doubled down by Trump so that now everything is so political about Israel. And, you know, Democrats and Republicans for the longest time, look at our financial support, military support, pro-Israel. And now Netanyahu at Trump's behest is dividing that. There's going to be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Calling it an occupation is kind of a divisional.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- in the White House and they're going to, you know, put in a position --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And so the Israeli prime minister, he is the one that's being divisive, not the squad?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, I will agree with Juan on one thing. And that is, this does push the Democratic Party further away from Israel because Democrats are taking the side of Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar instead of a long-standing ally. And you could say, well, they are Americans, they are congresswomen, that is why we are doing it. But if you look at the record and why they were not allowed into the country, the group they are going with celebrate suicide bombers who not only kill Israelis but also Americans. They glorify terrorists who kill children. So, that's one reason that they are left out. And during their press conference, and this is exactly what they are going for, they are talking about so much misinformation, right? They are acting like this is about Benjamin Netanyahu when it's about BDS which is a movement that's been around for far longer than one political party either in the U.S. or in Israel. And it's about not allowing the country to exist. Rashida Tlaib talks about the walls in Israel not being effective. Actually, they are at keeping suicide bombers out of Israel. And so there's a lot of things that they're putting on the table that they don't want to talk about in terms of human rights that don't jive with the leftist narrative. Just today, the Palestinian authority banned all LGBTQ activity in the West Bank, while Israel has one of the largest gay rights parades in the world. So they're going to have to figure out, Democrats, whether they actually support real human rights in the Middle East which come with Israel, including for Arab-Israelis, or whether they support two congresswomen who are associated with group who celebrate suicide bombings against American citizens.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And wasn't this whole thing exposed as a stunt, Greg, when the Israeli government let Tlaib come in to visit her grandmother on humanitarian grounds and then she said no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who uses their grandmother as a prop? She wrote in a letter this may be the last time I see my grandmother, then she decides not to see her grandmother. And then -- but she finds time to post this other cartoon. I'm going to say I don't trust her. I don't trust anybody that would use their grandmother in such a manner. She should apologize to her grandmother, Dana, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, also, the two of them could've gone on the trip the week before with 51 members of Congress -- 30 Republicans, 21 Democrats.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They could've all gone together and then -- and from what I heard from that trip, all views were expressed and these views could have been expressed --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's not what Kevin McCarthy says. Kevin McCarthy, Republican, leader of the Republicans in the House says, "Yes, they should've been let in. Everybody should go. But this is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, but I was saying they should've gone with the whole group.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think they have to go by anybody's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But aren't we paying for it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- members of the United States Congress.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Aren't we paying for it, Juan?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Should they go with a group?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Aren't we paying for them so it would be cheaper as a group.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- with this group.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Juan, should they go with the group that says anti-terrorism?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- members of Congress have always been allowed to go --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- without our president telling another nation's president --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But not with this group.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- oh no, don't let my political opponents in. That to me is -- and now, this effort to say something about the ambassadors, they are just proxies for Netanyahu and Trump.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Can I just say one more thing about the aid point that Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib were making. They're saying well, we give Israel $3 billion in aid every year. Aid to Israel is actually an investment because in return for that they give us technology, they give us counterterrorism operations. They stop dozens of terrorist attacks last year in 20 different countries. The Palestinians use our aid, our taxpayer money to pay terrorists and their families to kill Americans and Israelis. So, that's the difference. What's the return on investment when it comes to Israel? We get a lot in return for the aid that we're giving them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And maybe they didn't go to Israel with the other delegation. Maybe they had an appointment that they couldn't change. Those things, you know, there are sometimes conflicts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- Netanyahu just had to comment and criticized an American president in our country. Maybe we should have kept him out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think Obama had denied entry to --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- someone from Israel. I think it was in 2012, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, stop.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, it goes both ways. Elizabeth Warren's DNA debacle is back and she's forced to apologize again for lying about her Cherokee heritage. See that, next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Elizabeth Warren seeing a surge in the polls but an old controversy continues to haunt her on the campaign trail. The 2020 Democratic hopeful apologizing again for to Native-Americans for her previous Cherokee heritage claims.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), PRESDIENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Like anyone who has been honest with themselves, I know that I have made mistakes. I am sorry for harm I have caused. I have listened and I have learned a lot. And I am grateful for the many conversations that we've had together. It is a great honor to be able to partner with Indian Country, and that's what I've tried to do as a senator, and that's what I promise I will do as president.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, that was her today at a big event, Jesse. Now, a contrary view could be that this speaks to the strength of her campaign that she went to this event knowing that she would have to do this even, you know, she could've had a scheduling conflict. Who knows when is a scheduling conflict, like a dentist appointment you can't change.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. I think it was a whitewash. The moderator of the event endorsed her. And then they agreed ahead of time that she would not be asked about her fake heritage claims. And then on the eve of the event, she scrubbed the video where she released her DNA results from her campaign website. So, she's got terrible political instincts and she's a phony. And what she did to Native Americans was -- some people say a lot worse than what Trump has done to minorities. If you think about what she did, she stole their identity. Then she use that fake identity to suppress the minorities' access to higher education jobs. And then she profited from the fake identity. And then when she got busted on it, when President Trump mocked her, she said "Oh, that's an ethnic slur, Pocahontas." That's about as an ethnic slur as Fredo. It doesn't even make any sense. What's happening now is she is up in the polls because she's getting some Bernie boroughs (ph) behind her. But she's got a very irritating demeanor. Black Americans don't really love her that much. Wall Street hates her. So, I think she's just -- it's another landslide victory for the president if she gets the nomination.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, one thing is, that the president said the other night in his rally that he had hit her hard on the issue, but now she's coming back so she's going to have to do it again. But because it's so competitive on the Democratic side, why do you think that none of the other Democrats go after her about it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I will tell you, as a black lesbian, I believe that it is important that she reach out to them to get this past her. Here's the problem though. What is she apologizing for? Like, I'm not sure. Because that amazing video that you mentioned scrubbed, vindicated her, right? She was 1/17000 Native American and she played that up, so. Is she apologizing for perpetuating the lie? Is she apologizing for the impersonation, the exaggeration or the exploitation? Remember, she used this to get ahead and the law school used her lie to get ahead by saying like, we have the first female minority lawyer. Was it Harvard, I believe? So, that's why I don't give anymore money to that school. But anyway, and the media, like Jesse said, will pay this as some kind of, like calling her fauxcahontas or whatever. It's like calling a dumb person Einstein, right? It's like -- so I just think that I'm confused, as you could tell. I don't know what she's apologizing for. Is she admitting she lied or -- she said she's Native American?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In the Jonathan Martin "New York Times" piece last week, Juan, they said it was a story about her poll numbers better. And at the very end, they interviewed somebody who had gone to one of her events and they said, "She's so smart. She really has a plan." And the last line was, it's just that Pocahontas thing. And that was how he ended it. Is that on the minds in regards to electability against President Trump?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think people realize that this is what Trump has when it comes to Liz Warren. I mean, that's why he's back attacking her. She's rising in the polls. He goes after Sleepy Joe, who is Joe Biden, who's really on his mind and he's the most attacked by the president. But now, she's back in the picture and again because she is a strong candidate and a rising -- she has momentum. I mean, the fact that she went to this forum, that she was invited to this forum, indicates in the words of the man who hosted the forum, that this is a trivial issue for Native Americans. They don't think it's a big deal. But what you get is a situation where, you know what, she has big ideas, Dana, and she has ideas, policy ideas. So for the Native Americans, what they say is this Pocahontas thing is Trump's agenda. That's the way he puts people down. And it's trivial to us. What's important to us, her -- Elizabeth Warren's top issues; health care, education, helping young people get ahead, pay for that big tuition debt. And, you know what, saying to the very rich people in this country, hey, no more protections. No more too big to fail. You got to pay your taxes and deal with (inaudible). People are reacting to her as a passionate advocate, including Native Americans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One thing about her that's different to Hillary Clinton, Hillary Clinton never apologized for the e-mail scandal. And Elizabeth Warren has apologized a few times for this even though people aren't really sure what she apologized for.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But she has never admitted that she's not Native American. She's never said she's not Cherokee. She has parsed this line between I've caused all this pain --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- I'm sorry for that, but she's never said I'm sorry for using the 1/1024th may be Cherokee argument to put on my bar card in Texas that I was Native American or to get that first status as the first woman of color at Harvard Law School. So, I'm not clear on what she's apologizing for either. And I think if she had not gone to the forum, it probably would have looked worse --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- because she would have been avoiding the issue. So, she was in a little bit, a little loose (ph)

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, it might be a sign of strength, I guess, for her and within the Democratic Party that she went, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Also, in other Native American news, "The Washington Post" did a poll among Native Americans and they asked, what was the number one emotion that you felt when you saw the Washington Redskin mascot? And you know what the top one was?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Pride.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Pride. They like it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you know my number one reaction is?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Disgust.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because they're going to go 0-16?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And guess what --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because the Eagles are going to beat them twice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, we got to tell the audience. That's my team. I just don't like that name. I don't like it at all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How do you think I feel about the San Francisco Giants? I am a below average height person. My favorite baseball team is the Giants, Dana. Everyday I wake up and I go, I have to root for a team that towers over my diminutive stance.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That you could never achieve.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I could never achieve.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, this is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How do you think I feel?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know what, it's out of reach.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am not a protected class, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I though you were a black lesbian.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, that's true. I'm a short one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, President Trump and conservatives are furious over a leaked transcript from "The New York Times" staff meeting. We're going to tell you what it says, next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right. "The New York Times" being blasted for bias after a leaked transcript revealed its new plan to go after President Trump. The paper's executive editor forced to hold a crisis town hall meeting last week after liberal backlash for changing a headline about recent shootings. From "Trump Urges Unity Versus Racism" To "Assailing Hate But Not Guns." In the leaked transcript, the editor, Dean Baquet, is quoted as saying, "We build our newsroom to cover one story. We did truly well." But after Russia collusion fell apart, the editor says his paper is focusing on a new narrative, race. Here's a quote -- "Now, we have to regroup and shift resources and emphasis to take on a different story." So, Jesse, this transcript is revealing but it also I think solidified a lot of what we already knew.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. Well, it was revealing in a sense that they admitted that they were unable to take out Trump. They have admitted that they are not as influential as they think they are. And they admitted they are not journalists, that they are partisan activists. Because a real journalist would go back the last two years and look, how did this Russia hoax actually come into being? But they are spending no time looking back. They have turned a blind eye to it and then are now just looking at what else can take out Trump. Race, I don't believe will have the same type of effect against the president as the Russia thing did. You could see the rating for the cables that pushed that hoax, are not rebounding as they pivot to race. And approval for Donald Trump among Hispanics and Black Americans since January has actually gone up. So, it's also not a very inspiring message to say that the country is founded on racism, it's a racist nation, and we need to destroy it and institute socialism in order to heal it. That type of messaging to this country is racist and that Trump is racist that all Trump voters are racist are going to turn off the very voters that the Democrats are going to need to recapture those rust belt districts in order to win back the White House because race isn't going to work. It's got to be health care, education, as Juan said, and jobs.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Juan, you look like you have something to say in response to that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I do your honor. And I just want to see my time to Mr. Watters because I think he is indicting himself and I just want more of his testimony. Russia hoax?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Did you miss the entire Mueller report that said Russia interfered in the 2016 --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The hoax was there. It's collusion Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- to help Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was the hoax.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- it was -- this is what -- there was no finding of any collusion, no investigation. It was an investigation to conspiracy and they didn't find a conspiracy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let's just move on.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Juan, as a journalist, do you think this type of conversation about activism --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's just move on after he --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, because I said I would see the point to Jesse because I think he is indicting himself, but go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, as a journalist for many years --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- do you think that these conversations about the activism are appropriate?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well look, I think -- look, I just think you look at the numbers. We had a poll here at Fox last week -- it said two-thirds of Americans think he's tearing the country apart. And that includes by the way, more than 60 percent of white Americans. So, something is going on in terms of the social fabric. And if you're a journalist, how could you not pay attention to it. But to my mind, you know, it's like this is not a new topic for the "Times." "The Times" have been covering it. I think yesterday they had a magazine dedicated to slavery. So, this is something that they need to do. And I think that what you hear from Dean Baquet is look, we put a lot of effort into covering Mueller and the conspiracy argument, Jesse, and I think they did a pretty good job. They were way ahead of other people saying that they didn't think that Mueller was coming --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They didn't do a very good job, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think they -- in fact, I think they were ahead of saying, certainly, ahead of all those people who were over at the other channels feeding this conspiracy. They were not in that camp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, the other channels follow everything that's written in "The Times."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM
utterances.utterance: I think they may, but they didn't do it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. The conspiracy is that they are creating a framework to shape the news to lay out a blueprint so you can just slot in all the stories about race. Whether the polls say that they think Trump is tearing the country apart is irrelevant because it's the media that is creating the narrative that people hear about. The fact is the curtain is now pulled back. We see this and we are surprised. The rest of the media smirks because it's been this way all along, the problem. So why are they doing this? It's because racism is a quantity where in the media, the demand exceeds the supply. So they're going to have to keep creating this. They're going to have to keep doing this. And to your point, that slave story, the slave article was probably -- I didn't read it, but I'm assuming it was probably well- researched. It was probably well done, but I didn't read it. But now, my assumptions are this is all part of a greater narrative to paint Donald Trump as racist. So I'm going to look at everything they do as somehow artificially constructed to demonize somebody, and it's not going to stop. It's going to get worse. And we have to admit, this country overtime gets less racist. Do you think we're more racist now than we were in the 60's or the 50's or the 1860's? It's getting better, but they don't like that story. Things are going so well that they need to demonize everybody. So, right now, the Gray Lady is - this is bigger than Watergate. Gray Lady is Nixon and drag at this point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But you know, you're right. I think things are getting better in terms of race.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Of course, they are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In terms of like if I compare where my father was to where I am. I don't think there is any question. But I will say this look--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: End there, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anybody - I'm sorry?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: End your point there that you agree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, I know I was confirming something, but I think that anybody who has covered Trump as a real journalist knows that he has had trouble with the race issue all along. Federal suits about housing discrimination. The birther movement. Mexicans rape. I mean just I could go on Central Park Five. I wrote a book about this a year ago. That has nothing to do with somehow, it's suddenly discovered, we're going to make something out this. No, that's just been an issue with Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you take each one of those separately, they add up to very little. So that's why you have to list them.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think on the Russia thing, a lot of people that work in news, you had invested a lot of time to read all of their pieces and it was a lot of time and a lot of it was always hinting that Trump was behind it. And so, all the podcasts, all the things that they did. And I'm just like reporting the news. But I think one of the things that's happened is there is this generational change in the newsroom. So, like Dean Baquet, I don't think that he - I don't know exactly - I'm not going to try to put words in his mouth, but there is this generational change where now I think it's partly because of the way universities, trained journalists now that they're activists and just reporting the news. Like news organizations used to be worried that they might make their advertisers mad. You worked in magazines, right. They're not going to like to see that article next to their picture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're great product. That was their worry before. Now, they're worried about their own reporters. And I'm just trying to like just to report the news. Plus bashing the media is now a bipartisan sport. Whereas Bernie Sanders like figure out a way to get his base energized by bashing the media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But to your point, New York Times is no different than Media Matters. Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Because they're both pushing an agenda, a political ideological agenda.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And I'm glad you said that, Dana.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's not true at all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm glad you said that, Dana.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's not true, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana said that New York Times is no different than the Media Matters. She did.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right. Fact-check. Not true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: Well, Greenland, I don't know it got released somehow. It's just something we talked about. Essentially, it's a large real estate deal. A lot of things could be done. It's hurting Denmark very badly because they're losing almost $700 million a year carrying it. And strategically for the United States, it would be nice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. But the Prime Minister of Denmark, the country that officially controls Greenland, they're smacking down Trump's big real estate idea.

utterances.speaker: METTE FREDERIKSEN, PRIME MINISTER OF DENMARK

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Greenlandic. I did not know that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Katie, I was thinking to myself, wait a second, this is going to cost a lot. It's going to be a bigger purchase. We already have a ballooning deficit. So, why is he focusing on real estate instead of focusing on us.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think that's why--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because we're doing great.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right. We have all the money. No, we are $22 trillion in debt. That is true, but this would be a foreign policy geopolitical decision that's being painted as a real estate deal. So, China is interested in the waters around Greenland, Russia is of course interested, and this is all about China because Greenland has a lot of resources, rare earth that we cannot get anywhere but China. So, we'd be able to get them there. I just want to say I think this is going to happen. Anybody who's in denial, it's going to happen. Manifest destiny Greenland is going to happen and I just--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. You giggled. Are you serious? Are you joking?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I'm mostly serious, very serious.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Mostly serious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Mostly serious.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Harry Truman tried to buy it for $100 million back in the day. So, maybe for $1 billion, they would take it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

That way you know you get to keep 50 and everybody's flag stays intact. But like you said, vast mineral wealth and that's a buffer against the Russians and the Chinese. I think if you don't like this, you're not truly an American patriot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Mostly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: For Greenland.

utterances.utterance: Yes.

They're talking about the possible problems in the Arctic with China and Russia as competitors and a president would say, so what could we do. What do you have? And he goes around the table and somebody says, you could try to buy Greenland. That's actually a great idea. So that, I think how this all came up. It's not the wildest idea since Truman also tried to do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's interesting. You mean like this - he has some foresight.

utterances.utterance: There is a great reality show, it's called Flip This Country, it's basically if you look at Greenland, it's a fixer upper. Right. It's like the neighborhood, it's not that great. It's kind of far. It's got a big yard for the kids and the pets. You got 360 degree views all around. It's not really close to town though. So, it's a long walk to Canada. So, it has its pluses and minuses. I think as a sound real estate developer could probably get this thing together in a few months. But the great thing about this story is the way we respond to it is a proof of sound mental health. Like if you hear this story and you are immediately kind of grinning and you find it funny. And you don't react like oh god, this boorish Trump. This is just another Trump. You're healthy. Like this is a healthy thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm feeling pretty healthy

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A new study by New York University finds that a third of people who get high post on social media while under the influence, and a large portion said, they regretted their intoxicated actions. Now I like this study because I am this study. How many times I would tweet something rude after that third glass of wine and the next day, regret the tweet, not the wine. I learned that overtime I had to cut back on one or the other. So, out went the wine. And in came the vodka, but we're missing the good news. The study isn't about the destruction caused behind the wheel of a car. It's about the embarrassment caused in front of your smartphone screen. Wikipedia told me that between 1991 and 2017, the rate of drunk driving fatalities decreased 46 percent nationally and 68 percent under people 21, age 21. So, we find ourselves no longer steering into lampposts, instead we steer humiliating posts about our stupid thoughts, activities and selves into a ravenous public who happily seek another opportunity to dance on our shame, Pete O-Rourke once called booze liquid idiot. But our tweets are digital dumb, which is better because nobody ever drove a tweet into oncoming traffic and wiped out a family of five. So, consider it progress that more people are dying from embarrassment than internal injuries. If more high people are wrecking themselves online than on the road that's a win for all of us. We should all drink to that in moderation of course and certainly not your tweeter, Twitter, tweeter. So, I did--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is not where I thought that was going.
